ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

POLITICAL DETAINEES
(Publication of correspondence between Prime Minister's Office and Amnesty International of London)


    Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether he will publish the correspondence between his office and Amnesty International of London on the subject of Political Detainees.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): The correspondence between my office and Amnesty International of London is circulated herewith.

    Mr Speaker: Has the correspondence+(Appendix II, Cols. 855-60) been tabled?
POLITICAL DETAINEES(Cols 0855-0860)


Column: 766



    The Prime Minister: I think so. As I understand it, my Secretary has supplied enough copies.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): I would like to ask the Prime Minister whether he will consider the suggestion made by Amnesty to release those detainees who are prepared to leave the State of Singapore and Malaysia for purposes of furthering their studies?

    The Prime Minister: I think the Member for Anson has read the reply which my Secretary sent to Amnesty International.

    For the benefit of Members of the House who did not see the document, may I just refer to paragraph (5) of the letter by Anwar Ibrahim, my Secretary:

    `As in (4) above, the decision to detain and to release detainees rests with the Internal Security Council in which the Singapore Government has only three out of seven members. But the Singapore Government's three members will consider allowing detainees freedom to leave Singapore provided they are satisfied that the applicant who offers to give a written undertaking not to engage in politics abroad is one whose conduct in the past is not such as to make his words worth less than the paper they are typed on.'

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister is aware that that sort of condition invalidates the entire assurance given. Would he consider that whether these persons whose words he is not prepared to accept undertake political activities elsewhere or not cannot in any way damage the security of Malaya? If they go to territories like Australia or the United Kingdom or the United States of America, would he take into consideration the places to which they seek to go for the purpose of pursuing their studies?

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid that the statement made by the Member for Anson is somewhat naive in its approach if he believes that a place like London is innocuous. From our point of view, a great amount of energy and effort has been spent to counter the activities of Mr John Eber and

Column: 767

the Movement for Colonial Freedom. I see no reason why Mr John Eber should receive further assistance from more able united front Communist leaders. If we are convinced that any particular gentleman wishes to go to London for the salubrious air and to learn through the scholarship with which London and its universities are endowed, then we will seriously consider the proposition. But if - as the professional experts believe - there is a plan afoot to try, now that they are neutralised, to move them into positions where they can once again be put to good use, then, as I say, our three votes will not be used to help them. But if we are convinced that they really want to lead a quiet and peaceful life, then I say that there is no reason why we would not consider them for a job in the Ministry of Culture looking after dances and cultural shows - innocuous things like that.

SEMBAWANG BY-ELECTION
(Further Statement)


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether he has any further statement to make as to when it is proposed to hold a by-election for the Electoral Division of Sembawang.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Statistics Department is working at full capacity to complete the election registers by the end of this month, or the beginning of next. As I said at the last sitting, the Sembawang by-election will be held soon thereafter.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I remember right, we were assured at the last sitting that the by-election would take place within two months. May I ask the Prime Minister whether we can expect that by-election next month?

    The Prime Minister: First, I challenge the statement that the Member for Anson has attributed to me. You will notice that even when my Secretary writes to Amnesty International, he writes in very circumspect language.

    Mr David Marshall: Dictated by you.

Column: 768



    The Prime Minister: I hope he has in his association with me learned how to deal with difficult gentlemen who ask difficult questions. I would assure the Member for Anson that however insidious he can be, he would never find me committed in writing in this Assembly or outside to a categorical statement that it would take place within two months. He has not found it so even in this statement. What I have said is that it is hoped - and it is working at full capacity to the knowledge of all members of the civil service and the people outside. In fact, I have moved two machines from the City Council to help them. What machines are they?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): High-speed sorting machines.

    The Prime Minister: We have loaned from the City Council two high-speed sorting machines to the Statistics Department to discharge these functions more efficaciously. And my answer stands.

FIRST GENERAL ELECTIONS IN
SINGAPORE UNDER PROPOSED
MALAYSIA CONSTITUTION
(Request for Statement)


    3. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether he will make a statement on the subject of the first General Elections in Singapore under the proposed Malaysia Constitution, and whether any changes are contemplated in the existing constitutional position relating to general elections.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, there are two general elections which will arise with Malaysia. There again, I think the Member for Anson will notice that the preposition has been chosen carefully - "with" Malaysia.

    The first is the election of 15 seats to the Central Parliament. The second is the election of 51 seats to the State Assembly. As soon as the necessary legislation is ready, it will be tabled in this House for adoption.

    The boundary of the 15 seats will be decided by the Federal Elections Commission. But for the first elections to the

Column: 769

Central Parliament, there may not be sufficient Time for the Commission to delineate the 15 constituencies. So the 15 constituencies may have to be formed by joining up the 51 Assembly constituencies in threes and fours so as to give even representation throughout the island. Just in case the Federal Elections Commission cannot get on with the job in time, my colleague, the Minister for Home Affairs, will be introducing for First Reading a Bill meant for discussion in this House in Select Committee on the joining up of the seats in threes and fours within the next few days.

    A change contemplated relates to the Members elected to the 51 seats in the next Assembly. At present, individual Members of the Assembly, once elected, can hold their party to ransom by changing sides. In, future, it is proposed that when a person resigns or is expelled from the party on whose platform he was elected, he will automatically vacate his seat.

1960 REPORT OF DIVISION OF COMMERCE AND INDUSTRY
(Reason for delay in publication)


    4. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance why it took two years and three months to publish the Report of the Division of commerce and Industry for the year 1960.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply.

    I do not accept that a time lag of two scars and three months is unreasonable for the publication of the Annual Report of the Trade Division of my Ministry.

    The preparation of the Annual Report must wait upon completion of trade statistics for that year. Major reorganisation in the Ministry in 1961 necessarily engaged the officers in more urgent duties, and compilation of the 1960 Report had to be held in abeyance during the period.

Column: 770



    The Member for Anson was the Minister for Commerce and industry sometime during 1955/1956, and he will doubtless recollect that during his tenure of office, he did not publish the 1953/1954 Annual Report for the Ministry of Commerce and Industry.

    Mr David Marshall: Sir, I am reminded of the remark that one asks the organ-grinder and gets a reply from the monkey. But I would ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether he is seriously contending that two years and three months is a period indicative of efficiency in the Department in the production of so slim a document as that Annual Report.

    Mr Ramaswamy: I have said that the officers were engaged on some other urgent duties.

    Mr David Marshall: Ah, I hear the organ-grinder!

Column: 770

DECLINE IN 1960 EXPORTS TO
DOLLAR AREA AND NON-STERLING ASIAN COUNTRIES AS
COMPARED WITH 1959
(Request for Statement)


    5. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance whether he knows of any reasons why exports from Singapore in 1960 to the Dollar area and non-Sterling Asian countries should have declined as compared with 1959, and whether he will make a statement on developments in that sphere.

    Mr Ramaswamy (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply.

    In 1960, exports from Singapore to the dollar area declined by $62.2 million as compared with 1959 and exports to the non-Sterling Asian countries declined by $63.7 million.

    As far as the dollar area is concerned, the decrease in exports to the United States of America and Canada in 1960 as compared with 1959 was $59.7 million. Thus the decrease in exports to the dollar area was mainly owing to the decrease in exports to the United States of America and Canada. Similarly, the

Column: 771

decrease in exports from Singapore to Japan and China in 1960 as compared with 1959 was $67.7 million. Thus the decrease in exports to the non-Sterling Asian countries was due mainly to decrease in exports to Japan and China.

    In 1960, the export of rubber from Singapore came up to almost 53 per cent of total exports from Singapore. This gives us the first clue. The export of rubber from Singapore to the United States of America and Canada, and to Japan and China, expressed as a percentage of total exports from Singapore to these countries for the two years was more than 80 per cent in the case of the United States of America and Canada, and more than 70 per cent in the case of Japan and China. The decrease in total export to these countries was therefore mainly owing to a decrease in the export of rubber to these countries.

    The reasons for the decrease in the value and quantity of rubber exported from Singapore in 1960 as compared with 1959 have already been given on page 6 of the 1960 Annual Report of the Division of Commerce and Industry.

    Briefly, the sales from the American and British stockpiles and the greater use of synthetic rubber were the main causes of a decline in the export of natural rubber from Singapore in 1960.

    I should add that since then the volume of exports of rubber has increased from 598,000 tons in 1960 to 677,000 tons in 1961.

BEDOK RECLAMATION SCHEME
(Request for Statement)


    6. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for National Development whether he will make a statement on the Bedok Reclamation Scheme, and whether any extension thereof is being considered.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, I do not propose to add much to what the Prime Minister stated in his speech in the debate on the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's Speech of 8th April, 1963.

    The Housing and Development Board is proceeding with the pilot project which will entail the reclamation of 48 acres near the Fisheries School at Bedok,

Column: 772

8½ milestone. This project is expected to be completed in about three months' time. Initially, it is intended that the reclaimed area will be an open park. In the meantime, the technical and financial aspects of reclaiming further land from Bedok to Nicoll Highway are under consideration.

    Mr David Marshall: Could the Minister indicate the anticipated cost of this reclamation?

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: This pilot project will cost about $600,000 when completed.

POLICY ON ERECTION OF
ADVERTISEMENTS IN PUBLIC HIGHWAYS
(Request for Statement)


    7. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether he will make a statement of policy with reference to the erection of advertisements in or near public highways; and (b) whether any, and what licences, were granted to permit the erection of the advertising structure in North Bridge Road near the Capitol Car Park.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, the erection of advertisements in or near public highways may only be allowed if written permission has been obtained from the competent authority under the Planning Ordinance, provided the structure is not within an area prohibited for the exhibition of advertisements and complies with the requirements of the relevant by-laws. The competent authority, in examining any such development, takes into account many important considerations, such as aesthetic, amenity and traffic, and is advised by a Development Control Committee. The following were granted for the erection of the advertising structure in North Bridge Road, near the Capitol Car Park :-

    (1) Planning permission by the competent authority, on 14th February, 1962.

Column: 773



    (2) Approval to building plans by the Chief Building Surveyor's Department for the construction of the structure, on 11th May, 1962.

    (3) Licences for the exhibition of three sky signs and one advertisement by the Chief Building Surveyor's Department, on different dates in April and May this year.

    Mr David Marshall: I would ask the Minister whether he was aware personally, before these licences were granted, of the proposal for this monument to advertising, and whether having seen it now and the grave effect it has on the dignity of the waterfront of Singapore, he would consider cancelling those licences.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The first part of the supplementary question is in order, but the second part is completely out of order because it seeks an expression of opinion.

    Mr David Marshall: May I then take the first part and enquire from the Minister whether he was conscious of these plans before the granting of the licences?

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, as I have said just now, licences from the Chief Building Surveyor's Department will only be considered and issued after the competent authority under the Planning Ordinance has approved the construction of such a structure.

    Mr David Marshall: Am I to have no reply to my question, Mr Speaker, Sir?

    Mr Speaker: Order. Perhaps that is quite an unfair question, because the Minister accepts responsibility, as he must.

    Mr David Marshall: In that case, may I ask the Minister this: having seen it, would he consider withdrawing those licences?

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: In all big cities like the City of Singapore, there are higher sky signs than the sky sign that is situated ---

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Sir, I think this sky sign is consonant with the sky sign for a city of Singapore's stature. I will not withdraw.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): A-no-ne!

    Mr David Marshall: A-no-ne is right!

2.53 p.m.
ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [7th June, 1963],

    "That the Assembly approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1963."

    Question again proposed.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, first, let me point out that this is the most unusual Time to have a Budget debate in Singapore. Half the year has already gone by and we are now asked to approve only the Budget for the second half of 1963. The first half year's Budget was passed in 1961, and according to the P.A.P., there would be "numerous complicated and onerous technical problems of details" involved because of the P.A.P. merger with the Federation on or before June 1963. But June has come by and there is still no merger. Where are the "complicated and onerous technical problems of details" involved in the present Budget that necessitate the present procedure? And how is the present Budget different in

Column: 775

essence from the usual Budgets that we see year after year, that it could not have been prepared earlier in December 1962? The reason for the present procedure is, of course, that the P.A.P. has no use of the Legislative Assembly other than to use it as a rubber stamp for P.A.P. machinations. Passing the Budget early in 1961 made it unnecessary for the P.A.P. to hold Legislative Assembly sittings again for a long period. And indeed, there has been no Assembly sitting for months at a stretch. This unprecedented parliamentary procedure, like the telescoping of the time-table for the present Budget debate, shows what parliamentary practice we have in Singapore today. We have already had a long Assembly holiday of eight months and an Assembly seat vacant for ten months. Today, the P.A.P. merely wears the garb of parliamentary democracy for the convenience of deceiving the people both inside and outside Singapore.

    There is hardly anything that one can enthuse about in the Budget statement of the Minister for Finance. As usual he talks of P.A.P. successes. But take away the grease, the paint and the make-up. What is there left to show? Like the previous years, the year 1962 has been another year of dismal failure. Funds had been voted for use by the Government on development projects in order that they may benefit the people. But what development projects do we see in 1962? Until today, the people of Singapore have not been told as to how funds had been spent on the development projects in 1962. A sum of $207 million had been voted in December 1961 for the 1962 Development Estimates. The whole of Singapore can see that the money has not been spent as was budgeted for. As the Minister himself has admitted in the statement, in 1962 there was a huge surplus of $97 million, just as there was a huge surplus of $110 million in 1961. What has happened to the surplus of $97 million in 1962? Why does the Minister not inform the House and the people of Singapore as to what he has done with the money - the people's money and not P.A.P.'s money?

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Not Barisan money either!

Column: 776



    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The Minister may try to hide all the ugly facts behind a mass of verbiage, but the people have the right to know the state of financial affairs of Singapore. It is the duty and responsibility of the Government to inform them of what it has done to their money - not P.A.P. money!

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): When did we say "P.A.P. money"?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Let the P.A.P. tell the people why there is repeated under-performance, and let the P.A.P. openly admit its own inefficiency and incompetence and even negligence in the matter. There has been too much boasting about this surplus which the Prime Minister claims is the result of P.A.P. efficiency and good government. We say that it is nothing of the sort, and let the P.A.P. admit this tact. If the surplus had come about as a result of unexpected windfalls due to a more efficient collection of revenue, then there would have been something to crow about. But if the surplus had come about as a result of funds voted for and passed in the Legislative Assembly not being used, then it could only have meant incompetent and bad government. It could only have been a source of shame to the P.A.P. and not a source of boasting and bragging. For the P.A.P. to go about telling the people that the surplus is due to the good government of the P.A.P. is therefore sheer deception. The people, of course, are not so easily deceived; nevertheless, the P.A.P. must be condemned for such attempted deception of the people, and we ask the P.A.P. not to repeat this deception. The Prime Minister goes round the constituencies. Let the Ministers here tell him not to brag about this surplus anymore.

    From all this, Sir, we can also see that the P.A.P. Ministers do not mean what they say. When they say success, they in fact mean failure. But however much slick talk the Minister may indulge in, he will not be able to get this past the people.

Column: 777



    The P.A.P. called the year 1961 the year of construction. But now we know that there is nothing constructive about 1961. It was a year of sell-out as far as we know ---

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: How?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: --- and there was a surplus of $110 million of work not done and money not used on the people ---

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Lee Khoon Choy): You must be blind.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The P.A.P. did not give a name to the year 1962. We can help them.

    Mr Rajaratnam: The year of fulfilment.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: It is quite clear that the year 1962 was a year of P.A.P. deceit and coercion. That is how they managed their 70 per cent in the referendum. If the 70 per cent was correct ---

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: 71 per cent.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: But what of 1963? What shall we call it?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The year of the Rabbit.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: We shall call it the year of surrender - abject surrender - in spite of all the brave talk of the Minister for Finance and the Prime Minister.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Barisan finance.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Four years of P.A.P. misrule have passed, and the time will come for the people to pass judgment on the Government. In the first two years, the P.A.P. Ministers spent most of their Time throwing their weight about with habitual arrogance. They abused civil servants, -

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng): You were one of them.

Column: 778



    Dr Lee Siew Choh: --- instituted pay cuts and generally insulted, threatened and intimidated people all around. To make things worse, taxes were raised on petrol and tobacco and the P.A.P. persisted in taking a tough line because at that Time the P.A.P. thought that it was an indispensable force. Today, with popular support gone, ---

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Really?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: --- the P.A.P. Ministers have to resort to the buying of votes in preparation for the coming elections. In fact, they are ready to do almost anything, and they are already bending themselves backwards to please every Tom, Dick and Harry. The Prime Minister has to run around attending dinner functions of clan associations and other private functions. He wears all sorts of head gears including turbans, and he is ready to do almost anything in order to ingratiate himself with all those whom he used to despise and ridicule not so very long ago. Pictures in the Straits Times showed the Prime Minister openly hugging the Minister for Farrer Park ---

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: What?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The Member for Farrer Park.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng: You have not had enough sleep.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: And today, they have even gone to the extent of giving medals and what-not to the civil servants ---

    Mr Rajaratnam: You did not get any.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: --- the very people whom the P.A.P. despised and bullied but yesterday!

    In all the years of P.A.P. misrule, we see broken promises, underfulfilment of projects, shortages in staff and equipment in the various Government departments. The Prime Minister wants to give the impression that he is concerned about the hospitals. Does he know that today all the various departments in the hospitals are short of equipment? The essential drugs are missing ---

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: You pinched them,

Column: 779



    Dr Lee Siew Choh: --- and there is increasing hardship for the people. The unemployment problem is worsening. In addition, of course, there is repression and the deprivation of the basic rights and freedoms of the people. Only in one department do the P.A.P. Ministers excel in, and that is the department of malicious distortion, deception and treachery. The P.A.P. excels in sell-outs. That is the only thing they are good in, nothing else.

    In the matter of the financial merger talks, in spite of all the brave talk of the Prime Minister, it is clear that the P.A.P. is already getting ready to surrender in toto to the Federation. This talk of limited common market terms is only meant to save the face of the Prime Minister in his abject surrender. The Minister for Finance still talks of independence through merger. But he cannot be serious. He was talking with his tongue in his cheek because there is no independence with the P.A.P. merger and the P.A.P. itself has admitted as much in the financial talks tussle with the Federation. If it really thinks that there is independence, why should it fight or pretend to fight? Therefore, let us get rid of this nonsense about independence through merger.

    The Minister also talks of finding the money to pay for new schools and houses. But although we had the money in hand in 1962, we nevertheless did not have the many new schools and hospitals. Nor the equipment and staff for them. We have surpluses which have merely been sent overseas for investment. In 1959, the surplus funds invested overseas amounted to $139 million. The sum increased to $249 million in 1960 and by 1961 the amount invested overseas had increased to $316 million. I do not wish to repeat what I have already said only two months ago in the debate on the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech. It can always be found in the Hansard. Unfortunately, the figures for 1962 have not come out yet. But I am sure that the figure for 1962 will be much higher than for 1961. The P.A.P.'s Five-Year Plan advocates the use of local funds for investment in Singapore. Today, we see that the P.A.P. has not only not brought back to Singapore money

Column: 780

invested overseas, but, on the contrary, it has increased the investment abroad. What good will money invested abroad do to the people of Singapore?

    The main problem in Singapore's economy remains the problem of unemployment. How are we to get enough jobs for the increasing number of unemployed in Singapore? Every year, more than 30,000 students leave school. What has the P.A.P. done to obtain jobs for all these job-seekers? How does the P.A.P. deal with this problem of - according to the Minister - sustaining the economic growth of Singapore to keep pace with the yearly increase in population? For four years, the P.A.P. has been playing politics. Although the Five-Year Plan in The Tasks Ahead was announced to the people before 1959, and the Four-Year Development Plan was prepared more than two years ago, no appreciable concrete results have been shown.

    The industrialisation programme has been left stagnating as a result of the P.A.P. playing politics and the Ministers' obsession to fix their political opponents. The Minister boasts of pioneer certificates for industries, that they will soon commence operation and provide jobs for 3,500 people, and of a range of goods, which if and when they go into production, will provide employment for 1,620 people. Even if these figures were realised, for the sake of argument, it still would not help the situation. In four years of P.A.P. misrule. 30,000 times 4, that is, 120,000 young men and women have left school to look for jobs. Where are the 120,000 jobs for these 120,000 people?
